author: Herald Staff
title: Servais takes over as Seattle manager
text:
Servais takes over as Seattle manager Herald Staff Saturday, October 24, 2015 comments Tweet The Seattle Mariners hired former big league catcher Scott Servais as their manager yesterday, giving the job to someone with ties to the new front office but no experience running a team.
The 48-year-old Servais replaces Lloyd McClendon , who was fired earlier this month after Seattle went 76-86. New Mariners general manager Jerry Dipoto made the announcement.
Servais worked the past five seasons as an assistant general manager for the Los Angeles Angels and worked alongside Dipoto for most of that time. Dipoto resigned as Angels GM on July 1.
The hiring makes Servais the 10th full-time and interim manager for the Mariners since the club’s last playoff appearance in 2001.
Servais spent time with Houston, the Cubs and San Francisco during his playing career.
After the Mariners won 87 games and missed the postseason by one game, Seattle finished in fourth place in the AL West. The regression led to the firing of general manager Jack Zduriencik in late August.
Seattle also reportedly interviewed former Red Sox catcher Jason Varitek for the job.
Hoops: Popovich named U.S. coach
Gregg Popovich , who has led the San Antonio Spurs to five NBA titles, will replace Mike Krzyzewski as the U.S. men’s basketball coach following the 2016 Olympics. USA Basketball said yesterday that Popovich will take over starting with 2017 training camp and lead the Americans into the 2019 Basketball World Cup and 2020 Olympics if they qualify.
Krzyzewski guided the Americans to consecutive Olympic gold medals and two world titles. . . .
Miami Heat guard Gerald Green was fined $25,000 by the NBA for making menacing gestures in an exhibition game.
Misc.: Ex-Louisville assistant resigns
Andre McGee resigned as assistant coach at University of Missouri-Kansas City yesterday, saying he could no longer do the job as he fights “false” allegations by an escort that he hired dancers to strip and have sex with recruits and players while coaching at Louisville, where he played.
Also, Rick Pitino , McGee’s former boss at Louisville, said he will skip ACC media day next week on the advice of counsel because of the allegations. . . .
Brett Stegmaier topped the leaderboard in the Shriners Hospitals for Children Open in Las Vegas in only his fifth career start on the PGA Tour. . . .
Justin Rose shot a 4-under 66 to grab a 1-shot lead at 9-under 131 after the second round of the Hong Kong Open. . . .
Ji Eun-hee took a 1-stroke lead over Lydia Ko in the LPGA Taiwan Championship in Taipei. . . .
Jimmy Roberts , a five-time Stanley Cup champion with the Montreal Canadiens and an original member of the St. Louis Blues, died yesterday. He was 75. . . .
The 34th annual Alumni Reunion-Hall of Fame banquet of the Boston Park League will be Nov. 13, at Lantana’s in Randolph. The BPL will induct six new Hall of Famers — Jay Adams (Triple D’s), Jason Kiley (Cannon Club), Brian Ferrari (Palmer Club), Sandy Gonzalez (Padres), Coley Lyons (Stockyard) and Harvey Soolman (Towne Club).
